content:
I am a PhD student in the Computer Science Department at UIUC, where I work with Prof. Ravishankar Iyer  in the DEPEND  group. My research focuses on design of techniques for automatic identification of safety-critical bugs, and smart-monitoring of systems and applications. My work is supported through NSF, DoE, Sandia National Laboratories, IBM, and NVIDIA. I am on the job market.
  News   Jonathan Petit, a Principal Engineer at Qualcomm Technologies, presented ideas from Bayesian Fault Injector in his keynote address at ESCAR 2019  --  Selected for ETS McCluskey Doctoral Thesis Award. Finals on May 15.   Won best paper award  for our ISSRE 2020 paper assessing self-driving cars.   SC 2020 paper  nominated for both the best paper and the best student paper.   Co-created "Dependable AI" course with my advisor. Suggestions are welcome.   Honored to be named the 2020 IBM Ph.D. Fellow    Bayesian Fault Injector (DSN 2019) designed for assessing autonomous vehicles received world-wide press coverage: Science Daily, Daily Illini , Guancha.cn, Space Daily, Eureka Alert, Sina Dataset release for the largest fault injection campaign on Cielo supercomputer.  -- Monet (NSDI 2020), used for high-performance interconnection network monitoring, is openly available. Source code, large-scale network congestion data. -- AVFI (DSN 2018), used for autonomous vehicle testing and assessment, is openly available. AVFI is widely being used by several researchers world-wide (including Samsung Research). Source code --    Professional Service  Journal Reviewer: TOC (2020), TON (2020), TDSC (2018), TPDS (2017), Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability (2017, 2018)    Conference Reviewer: ICML (2021), NeurIPS (2021)   External/Sub Conference Reviewer: EuroSys (2020 Shadow PC), SC (2017), HPCMASPA (2017)    Artifact Evaluation Reviewer: SOSP 2019

I am a PhD student in the Computer Science Department at UIUC, where I work with Prof. Ravishankar Iyer  in the DEPEND  group. My research focuses on design of techniques for automatic identification of safety-critical bugs, and smart-monitoring of systems and applications. My work is supported through NSF, DoE, Sandia National Laboratories, IBM, and NVIDIA. I am on the job market.

title: Saurabh Jha
Delay Sensitivity-driven Congestion Mitigation for HPC Systems
BayesPerf: Minimizing Performance Monitoring Errors Using Bayesian Statistics

ML-driven Malware that Targets AV Safety
Measuring Congestion in High-Performance Datacenter Interconnects

Holistic Measurement driven System Assessment
A Study of Network Congestion in Two Supercomputing High-Speed Interconnects

summary: The safety and resilience of fully autonomous vehicles (AVs) are of significant concern, as exemplified by several headline-making accidents. While AV development today involves verification, validation, and testing, end-to-end assessment of AV systems under accidental faults in realistic driving scenarios has been largely unexplored. This paper presents DriveFI, a machine learning-based fault injection engine, which can mine situations and faults that maximally impact AV safety, as demonstrated on two industry-grade AV technology stacks (from NVIDIA and Baidu). For example, DriveFI found 561 safety-critical faults in less than 4 hours. In comparison, random injection experiments executed over several weeks could not find any safety-critical faults.
title: ML-Based Fault Injection for Autonomous Vehicles: A Case for Bayesian Fault Injection
Monet - Blue Waters Network Dataset
Understanding Fault Scenarios and Impacts through Fault Injection Experiments in Cielo

summary: Availability of the interconnection network in high-performance computing (HPC) systems is fundamental to sustaining the continuous execution of applications at scale. When failures occur, interconnect recovery mechanisms orchestrate complex operations to recover network connectivity between the nodes. As the scale and design complexity of HPC systems increase, so does the system's susceptibility to failures during execution of interconnect-recovery procedures. This study characterizes the recovery procedures of the Gemini interconnect network, the largest Gemini network built by Cray, on Blue Waters, a 13.3 petaflop supercomputer at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA). We propose a propagation model that captures interconnect failures and recovery procedures to help understand types of failures and their propagation in both the system and applications during recovery. The measurements show that recovery procedures occur very frequently and that the unsuccessful execution of recovery procedures, when additional failures occur during recovery, causes system-wide outages (SWOs, 28 out of 101) and application failures (3.4 percent of all running applications).
title: Resiliency of HPC Interconnects: A Case Study of Interconnect Failures and Recovery in Blue Waters

summary: Autonomous vehicle (AV) technology is rapidly becoming a reality on U.S. roads, offering the promise of improvements in traffic management, safety, and the comfort and efficiency of vehicular travel. With this increasing popularity and ubiquitous deployment, resilience has become a critical requirement for public acceptance and adoption. Recent studies into the resilience of AVs have shown that though the AV systems are improving over time, they have not reached human levels of automation. Prior work in this area has studied the safety and resilience of individual components of the AV system (e.g., testing of neural networks powering the perception function). However, methods for holistic end-to-end resilience assessment of AV systems are still non-existent.
title: AVFI: Fault Injection for Autonomous Vehicles

summary: Autonomous vehicle (AV) technology is rapidly becoming a reality on U.S. roads, offering the promise of improvements in traffic management, safety, and the comfort and efficiency of vehicular travel. The California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) reports that between 2014 and 2017, manufacturers tested 144 AVs, driving a cumulative 1,116,605 autonomous miles, and reported 5,328 disengagements and 42 accidents involving AVs on public roads. This paper investigates the causes, dynamics, and impacts of such AV failures by analyzing disengagement and accident reports obtained from public DMV databases. We draw several conclusions. For example, we find that autonomous vehicles are 15 - 4000Ã- worse than human drivers for accidents per cumulative mile driven; that drivers of AVs need to be as alert as drivers of non-AVs; and that the AVs' machine-learning-based systems for perception and decision-and-control are the primary cause of 64% of all disengagements.
title: Hands Off the Wheel in Autonomous Vehicles?: A Systems Perspective on over a Million Miles of Field Data
Fault Injection-based System to Assess  the Safety and Reliability of Autonomous Vehicles to  Faults and Errors
Holistic Measurement-Driven System Assessment
Analysis of Gemini Interconnect Recovery Mechanisms: Methods and Observations
Improving Main Memory Hash Joins on Intel Xeon Phi Processors: An Experimental Approach
BbmTTP: Beat-based Parallel Simulated Annealing Algorithm on GPGPUs for the Mirrored Traveling Tournament Problem
Exploiting Data Parallelism in the YConvex Hypergraph Algorithm for Image Representation Using GPGPUs
P-HGRMS: A Parallel Hypergraph Based Root Mean Square Algorithm for Image Denoising
Resiliency for Extreme Scale Systems
